This case having been finally heard on 04.02.2025 and this Court on

10.02.2025 pronounced the following: -
JUDGMENT

1. This is a case instituted upon the Final report filed by Sub Inspector of
Police, City Traffic Police Station in Crime No.3338/2013 for the offences
punishable under Sections 279, 337 and 304 A of the Indian Penal Code, 1860
(hereinafter referred to as ‘the IPC’).
2. The Prosecution allegation in brief is as follows: Accused was the driver of
the Autorickshaw bearing Registration No. Kl 01 BA 9510. He drove the vehicle
from Sasthamangalam to Vellayambalam on Sasthamangalam-Vellayambalam Roa,
rashly, negligently and in a manner so as to endanger human life and at high speed
about on 04.06.2023 at 09:30 PM. The right side of car hit on the front right side of
the motor cycle bearing Registration No. KL 02 Temp 851, driven by the since
deceased in the same direction along with the Informant as its pillion rider, when
the car immediately and in high-speed drove towards the right side and took an
immediate U-turn, on the road in front of Indira Bhavan. Due to its impact,
Informant sustained injuries on his head, right leg and right hand and the since
deceased sustained grievous injuries on his head and legs. He was initially taken to
KIMS hospital and later to Medical College Hospital, Thiruvananthapuram.
Thereafter, on 29.06.2013 at 9.45 pm, the since Deceased succumbed to his
injuries, while undergoing treatment. Thus, the Accused is alleged to have
committed the above stated offences.
3. This Court took cognizance in respect of offences under Sections 279, 337
and 304 A of the IPC. On issuance of process, the Accused entered appearance. He
was enlarged on bail. He was represented by a Counsel of his own choice. Copies
of all relevant prosecution records were furnished to him. The particulars of
offence under Sections 279, 337 and 304 A of the IPC were read over and
explained to him, to which he pleaded not guilty and claimed to be tried.

3
4. From the side of Prosecution, CWs, 3, 1, 5, 17, 2 and 16 were examined as
PWs1 to 6 respectively and Exhibits P1 to P12 were marked, amongst which
Exhibits P9 to 11 were marked subject to Proof. CW6 is no more and his death
certificate was produced and CW7 did not turn up before the Court despite having
effected steps under Section 82 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (hereinafter
referred to as the CrPC). The remaining witnesses (CWs4, 8 to 15) were given up
by the Learned APP. The Accused was examined Section 313(1)(b) of the CrPC and
he denied all the incriminating circumstances against him and claimed innocence..
No Defence evidence was adduced.
5. Heard both sides and perused relevant documents. The following points
arise for consideration.
a. Has the Accused driven the aforesaid vehicle rashly, negligently in a
manner endangering the life of since deceased and PW2, causing injury to
them and thereby committed the offence punishable under Section 279 of
the IPC as alleged?
b. Has the Accused driven the aforesaid vehicle rashly, negligently in a
manner endangering the life of since deceased and PW2, causing hurt to
them and thereby committed the offence punishable under Section 279 of
the IPC as alleged?
Cc. Has the Accused by so driving the aforesaid vehicle in rash or
negligent manner hit the vehicle of since deceased and caused him to
succumb to his injuries, and thereby committed the offence punishable u/S.
304 A of the IPC as alleged?
d. If so, what shall be the proper sentence to be awarded?
6. Points (a) to (c): These points are considered together for the sake of
brevity and to avoid repetition.

A

PW1 denied having witnessed the incident and having given statement to
that effect as well as having identified the Accused. He deposed against the case of
the Prosecution.

PW2 deposed that he sustained injuries in the incident and that the since
deceased is his friend. The incident occurred to him at Sasthamangalam in front of
KPCC office. Though he deposed that he doesn’t remember having given the
statement to the police; he identified his signature in Exhibit P1. He deposed that
he was unconscious and doesn’t remember the incident exactly.

PW3 deposed that he was present during the inquest proceedings of the
since deceased and attested to the same as witness in Exhibit P2 Inquest Report.

PW4, the Investigating Officer deposed that he took over the investigation,
completed inquest proceedings of the since deceased and prepared Exhibit P2
Inquest Report. He inspected the car and its records produced; prepared Exhibit
P3 Vehicle Mahazar. The arrest of the Accused was recorded by him and the
Accused was enlarged on bail bond. Exhibit P4, Scene Plan prepared by the Village
Officer is also produced by him. Exhibit P5 is the postmortem report which on
receipt, was produced before this Court. The vehicle was inspected by the AMVI
and Exhibits P6 and 7 Inspection Reports are produced before the Court and
thereafter it was released on Third Party bail bond. He identified the signature of
CW16 in Exhibit P8 FIR.

PW5 deposed that he used to work at Indus Motors Sales Department at
Pattom. The incident occurred during 2013-14 and he doesn’t remember the exact
date. It was around 10:00 PM in between Vellayambalam and Sasthamangalam. He
deposed that he was on his two-wheeler and found people gathered there and saw
a bike involved in an accident; but not the person who sustained injury. He denied
having given statement to the police and deposed that his address was given to the
police. He categorically denied having given statements to the police with respect
to having witnessed the incident; the identity of the car, injured and the driver; the
reason for the incident; when the Learned APP drew his attention to those
statements by putting specific questions. He further deposed to have seen a car as

5
well. During the cross-examination, he deposed that he did not witness the alleged
incident and he reached only pursuant to fifteen minutes of the alleged accident.

PW6 deposed that on the basis of the intimation received from Medical
College, he went there on 05.06.2013 and recorded Exhibit P1 FIS and registered
Exhibit P8 FIR thereafter. He deposed that he had recorded Exhibit Pl(a) Body
Note of the PW2. He had visited the place of occurrence, inspected the same and
prepared Exhibit P12 Scene Mahazar.

This Court has carefully gone through the materials on record and
considered the submissions of the respective parties. On going through the
evidence on the record, it can be seen that PW1, the occurrence witness deposed
against the version of the Prosecution. PW5, the other occurrence witness has no
consistent case and he also deposed against the version of the Prosecution.
Further, the contradictions in the deposition of the PW5 is not proved as and the
same have not been put to the Investigating Officer. Though PW2, admits of
having sustained injury, he has no case that it was the Accused who had allegedly
hit his vehicle on theirs. The remaining witnesses were given up by the Learned
Assistant Public Prosecutor. There is nothing on record as revealed from the
deposition of the witnesses so as to implicate the Accused to the alleged incident
that the Accused had driven his car in a rash and negligent manner, at high-speed
causing the injured to succumb to his injuries. Nothing has been brought out in
evidence to the effect to prove the ingredients of the offences alleged. The
Prosecution has failed to substantiate its case by adducing proper evidence and
thereby failed to prove the guilt of the Accused beyond reasonable doubt. Hence
Points (a) to (c) are found in favour of the Accused.

7. Point d: In light of analysis of the points hereinabove, since those are found
in favour of the Accused, no sentence is to be awarded to the Accused.

8. In the result, the Accused is found not guilty of having committed the
offence punishable under Sections 279, 337, 304 A of the IPC. Hence, the Accused

6
is acquitted of the said offences under section 255(1) of CrPC. His bail bond stands
canceled and he is set at liberty.
(Dictated to my Confidential Assistant, transcribed and typed by her, corrected by
me and pronounced in open court on this the 10* day of February, 2025)
Judicial Magistrate of First Class-I
Thiruvananthapuram
